segment.source: Learn about the whitespace processing rules as used by XAML.
segment.target: Learn about the whitespace processing rules as used by XAML.

segment.source: XAML and whitespace
segment.target: XAML and whitespace

segment.source: XAML and whitespace
segment.target: XAML and whitespace

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: Learn about the whitespace processing rules as used by XAML.
segment.target: Learn about the whitespace processing rules as used by XAML.

segment.source: Whitespace processing
segment.target: Whitespace processing

segment.source: Consistent with XML, whitespace characters in XAML are space, linefeed, and tab.
segment.target: Consistent with XML, whitespace characters in XAML are space, linefeed, and tab.

segment.source: These correspond to the Unicode values 0020, 000A, and 0009 respectively.
segment.target: These correspond to the Unicode values 0020, 000A, and 0009 respectively.

segment.source: By default this whitespace normalization occurs when a XAML processor encounters any inner text found between elements in a XAML file:
segment.target: By default this whitespace normalization occurs when a XAML processor encounters any inner text found between elements in a XAML file:

segment.source: Linefeed characters between East Asian characters are removed.
segment.target: Linefeed characters between East Asian characters are removed.

segment.source: All whitespace characters (space, linefeed, tab) are converted into spaces.
segment.target: All whitespace characters (space, linefeed, tab) are converted into spaces.

segment.source: All consecutive spaces are deleted and replaced by one space.
segment.target: All consecutive spaces are deleted and replaced by one space.

segment.source: A space immediately following the start tag is deleted.
segment.target: A space immediately following the start tag is deleted.

segment.source: A space immediately before the end tag is deleted.
segment.target: A space immediately before the end tag is deleted.

segment.source: East Asian characters is defined as a set of Unicode character ranges U+20000 to U+2FFFD and U+30000 to U+3FFFD.
segment.target: East Asian characters is defined as a set of Unicode character ranges U+20000 to U+2FFFD and U+30000 to U+3FFFD.

segment.source: This subset is also sometimes referred to as CJK ideographs.
segment.target: This subset is also sometimes referred to as CJK ideographs.

segment.source: For more information, see http://www.unicode.org.
segment.target: For more information, see http://www.unicode.org.

segment.source: "Default" corresponds to the state denoted by the default value of the xml:space attribute.
segment.target: "Default" corresponds to the state denoted by the default value of the xml:space attribute.

segment.source: Whitespace in inner text, and string primitives
segment.target: Whitespace in inner text, and string primitives

segment.source: The above normalization rules apply to inner text within XAML elements.
segment.target: The above normalization rules apply to inner text within XAML elements.

segment.source: After normalization, a XAML processor converts any inner text into an appropriate type like this:
segment.target: After normalization, a XAML processor converts any inner text into an appropriate type like this:

segment.source: If the type of the property is not a collection, but is not directly an Object type, the XAML processor tries to convert to that type using its type converter.
segment.target: If the type of the property is not a collection, but is not directly an Object type, the XAML processor tries to convert to that type using its type converter.

segment.source: A failed conversion here results in a XAML parse error.
segment.target: A failed conversion here results in a XAML parse error.

segment.source: If the type of the property is a collection, and the inner text is contiguous (no intervening element tags), the inner text is parsed as a single String.
segment.target: If the type of the property is a collection, and the inner text is contiguous (no intervening element tags), the inner text is parsed as a single String.

segment.source: If the collection type cannot accept String, this also results in a XAML parser error.
segment.target: If the collection type cannot accept String, this also results in a XAML parser error.

segment.source: If the type of the property is Object, then the inner text is parsed as a single String.
segment.target: If the type of the property is Object, then the inner text is parsed as a single String.

segment.source: If there are intervening element tags, this results in a XAML parser error, because the Object type implies a single object (String or otherwise).
segment.target: If there are intervening element tags, this results in a XAML parser error, because the Object type implies a single object (String or otherwise).

segment.source: If the type of the property is a collection, and the inner text is not contiguous, then the first substring is converted into a String and added as a collection item, the intervening element is added as a collection item, and finally the trailing substring (if any) is added to the collection as a third String item.
segment.target: If the type of the property is a collection, and the inner text is not contiguous, then the first substring is converted into a String and added as a collection item, the intervening element is added as a collection item, and finally the trailing substring (if any) is added to the collection as a third String item.

segment.source: Whitespace and text content models
segment.target: Whitespace and text content models

segment.source: In practice, preserving whitespace is of concern only for a subset of all possible content models.
segment.target: In practice, preserving whitespace is of concern only for a subset of all possible content models.

segment.source: That subset is composed of content models that can take a singleton String type in some form, a dedicated String collection, or a mixture of String and other types in lists, collections, or dictionaries.
segment.target: That subset is composed of content models that can take a singleton String type in some form, a dedicated String collection, or a mixture of String and other types in lists, collections, or dictionaries.

segment.source: Even for content models that can take strings, the default behavior within these content models is that any whitespace that remains is not treated as significant.
segment.target: Even for content models that can take strings, the default behavior within these content models is that any whitespace that remains is not treated as significant.

segment.source: Preserving whitespace
segment.target: Preserving whitespace

segment.source: Several techniques for preserving whitespace in the source XAML for eventual presentation are not affected by XAML processor whitespace normalization.
segment.target: Several techniques for preserving whitespace in the source XAML for eventual presentation are not affected by XAML processor whitespace normalization.

segment.source: : Specify this attribute at the level of the element where whitespace needs to be preserved.
segment.target: : Specify this attribute at the level of the element where whitespace needs to be preserved.

segment.source: Note that this preserves all whitespace, including the spaces that might be added by code editors or design surfaces to align markup elements as a visually intuitive nesting.
segment.target: Note that this preserves all whitespace, including the spaces that might be added by code editors or design surfaces to align markup elements as a visually intuitive nesting.

segment.source: Whether those spaces render is again a matter of the content model for the containing element.
segment.target: Whether those spaces render is again a matter of the content model for the containing element.

segment.source: We don't recommend that you specify at the root level, because the majority of object models don't consider whitespace as significant one way or another.
segment.target: We don't recommend that you specify at the root level, because the majority of object models don't consider whitespace as significant one way or another.

segment.source: It is a better practice to only set the attribute specifically at the level of elements that render whitespace within strings, or are whitespace significant collections.
segment.target: It is a better practice to only set the attribute specifically at the level of elements that render whitespace within strings, or are whitespace significant collections.

segment.source: Entities and nonbreaking spaces: XAML supports placing any Unicode entity within a text object model.
segment.target: Entities and nonbreaking spaces: XAML supports placing any Unicode entity within a text object model.

segment.source: You can use dedicated entities such as nonbreaking space (in UTF-8 encoding).
segment.target: You can use dedicated entities such as nonbreaking space (in UTF-8 encoding).

segment.source: You can also use rich text controls that support nonbreaking space characters.
segment.target: You can also use rich text controls that support nonbreaking space characters.

segment.source: Be cautious if you are using entities to simulate layout characteristics such as indents, because the run-time output of the entities vary based on a greater number of factors than would the general layout facilities, such as proper use of panels and margins.
segment.target: Be cautious if you are using entities to simulate layout characteristics such as indents, because the run-time output of the entities vary based on a greater number of factors than would the general layout facilities, such as proper use of panels and margins.
